author: MarcusAgrippa

title: Trautman Hook (OPP) - both left and right version parts

description.text: I got the OPP (Open Prosthetics Project) Trautman hook STL files a while ago but only now caught up with designing and printing parts. So I tried whether the model would print, assemble and work and turns out it does. I started by adding both left and right prosthetic hook files so I could print me the right one ; ) After testing a PLA version, I got the parts in steel via Shapeways http://www.shapeways.com/shops/swisswuff and documented the assembly http://www.swisswuff.ch/tech/?p=7037.

Square tube rotating -270 degree around "harmonic" knot curve. Curve: r(t)= (.41 Cos(t) - .18 Sin(t) - .83 Cos[2 t] - .83 Sin[2 t] - .11 Cos[3 t] + .27 Sin[3 t]),
(.36 Cos(t) + .27 Sin(t) - 1.13 Cos[2 t] + .30 Sin[2 t] + .11 Cos[3 t] - .27 Sin[3 t]),
(.45 Sin(t) - .30 Cos[2 t] +1.13 Sin[2 t] - .11 Cos[3 t] + .27 Sin[3 t]) This parameterization is credited to Aaron Trautwein in a paper by Louis Kauffman on "Harmonic Knots". animation of similar knot: http://vimeo.com/79214087

author: Reidyoung

description.text:
Top bushing for RST Gila T6 fork. Model is created with DesignSpark Mechanical, source is provided.

STL file is prepared for ABS filament and sizes are changed a little. Actual diameters should be 30.1 mm (inner) and 33 mm (outer).

Since Gila is only a fork emulator, do not expect that it will work better with these new bushings. This is only a replacement for the old completely worn out ones created to prevent extra loud fork knock on brake use.

Agua is a stratovolcano located in Sacatepéquez in Guatemala . Constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.2 million facets). It was made using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

author: hellriser

description.text:
Three Versions:

The Laser Holder2 and Receiver2 ( and the PIR mount in other post) work with the BackPlate.

Use the Holder and Receiver for mounting on a base... See my PIR post for info on pivot.

Use the BackPlate to enable pivoting of the sensors. BackPlate is good for mounting without pellet. I use 6mm plastic pellets (Airsoft / similar) for the pivot bearing.

Laser_Holder2 and Receiver2 : Install sensors from the front side and use glue/potting as needed.

Laser_Holder and Receiver :Install sensors from the back side...

Update - Added: Laser Holder & Receiver 'Shorty' versions (reduced height)

Be sure to adjust your laser's focus before gluing/potting. Didn't know you can adjust them? Well, you can on many brands - the cap turns on the body.

description.text:
I recently bought a zombie survival road trip game called "Hit Z Road," and, after playing with some friends, decided that the game would feel more real if the cardboard bottle cap tokens were replaced with bottle caps. I don't drink many beverages in bottles with metal caps (beer or soda), so figured I would throw something together in Blender to print out.

The game requires 90 tokens in 3 different colors - Red, Blue and Yellow. So far, I've printed the red and blue, and will start the yellow tonight. They don't require any support, and they print well in sets of 9 or 10 (about an hour per plate).

Since these are game tokens, I didn't bother with authenticity or accuracy in the model - they're roughly the same size as a standard bottle cap and give the general impression, but I made the walls thicker and cut out a lot of the fiddly details. I plan to print out round stickers for the tops to complete them and make them work with the game.

As always, comments and suggestions are welcomed and encouraged!

Monoprice Maker Select i3

Supports:

Infill:

100%

Notes:

You could print them at a higher resolution, or with less infill, but it doesn't save much time nor greatly affect the quality of the pieces.

Printed at around 50mm print speed on a glass bed (hairspray adhesive) in ESun PLA+ (red) and Hatchbox PPLA (blue) - 210 degrees (my fan drops the temp down to about 200 during printing).

author: Bogomi67

description.text:
Cathal Garvey issued a challenge on the Thingiverse list a few hours ago, "Mouse get!" The challenge is to build a humane mouse trap that can be printed on a Makerbot, and that will trap a mouse and keep him in! 
Uploaded here is my attempt at designing such a trap. I'm printing it now, and will test it once it's fully printed (in a few hours.) It's not the most material efficient design, but I think it should foot the bill for a maximum security mouse trapping and storage facility. In fact, if you print it out of PLA, I'm willing to bet that this trap would stand up to a mouse wielding heavy artillery (heavy for a mouse, that is.) 
The idea is that when the mouse steps on the ramp, the support will be pulled away and the trap will close quite tightly. I tried to build it myself, but the bottom piece failed part of the way through because of some issues I'm having with my bot.

• Print one top and one bottom piece.
  • Insert a pin through the holes of the top and bottom pieces so that the top acts as a door, closing the trap.
  • Duct-tape a toothpick to the bottom of a piece of thick, noncorrugated cardboard, and tape that to the bottom of the trap so that it forms a ramp in the back of the trap. It should lie flat for now.
  • Find a piece of fairly thick, non-corrugated cardboard, cut a 1cm by 4cm strip, and fold it in half. This will be the stand that prevents the trap from closing. Prop it up under the door, so that the angle is pointing outward like the head of an arrow.
  • Place a rubber band around the entire trap. You will probably have to keep the cardboard support folded with your fingers so it doesn't collapse.
  • Tie a piece of string to the bottom of the support. Hot-glue it there if you feel like it.
  • Tie the other end, fairly tightly, to the toothpick so that the ramp is lifted.
  • Place bait on the ramp and wait.

remixed_from.title: Parametric Spring Contacts Battery Box for AA Cells

description.text:
Remix of ffleurey's excellent AA battery holder. Uses springs/tabs shown in photo, about £1 for ten pairs on ebay.

66mm model is designed for Samsung ICR18650-26F (pink flat top) and unprotected GTL red Li-Ion's. Its more parameterised than the original and has some code tidying and the solder tab meets the wire channel now, also removed +/- text from the bottom which didn't slice/print on the original. A bit wider too. Test printed and they are pretty tight length-wise, might need to make it longer when I get the battery contacts in the post.

69mm model fits Soshine LiFePo4 black and Panasonic/Sanyo NCR18650A green/red li-ions but doesn't have as many optimisations as the above, so if you want to edit one, use the 66mm.

Unfortunately the battery springs/plates I received from ebay are 19x12 not 14.5x9 so i had to modify the design for my latest project - see the wood-colour photo with the pink battery and the 3 green boxes, and battery_box_bigcontacts.*, it also has no screw tabs and a wider wire channel as I wanted both wires to come out of the same side. Removed the polarity markings as they didn't print well.

description.text:
*Edit 12/21/16 - A few people using Slic3r have had issues getting some of these to slice properly so I'll be uploading updated STLs later today that should fix the issue.

Terrain pieces for Talisman 4th Edition board game. They range in size and height but all of them are scaled to fit in their corresponding board space while still leaving room for characters to occupy the same space. All of the models can be printed without supports, brims, or rafts with the exception of the Crown of Command piece. For that one I recommend supports touching everywhere, line support pattern and a low 5-10% support density.
Models include The Graveyard, Village, Mines, Dice with Death, City, Tavern, Crown of Command, Warlocks Cave, Temple, Vampires Tower, Chapel, Castle, Ruins, Crypt, Pits, and the Portal of Power with plans to add a few more in the near future.

And if you like Talisman make sure you check out my Talisman card tray designs as well !

With so many small and separate pieces it can be tricky to get all of them to adhere perfectly. I could also upload a version that has the buildings all attached to the base. comments.text: A raft is a temporary bottom layer that all the pieces would be printed on top of. Imagine a flat rectangle that is slightly larger in length and width than all the individual pieces. Since its one larger solid piece you don't have to worry about all those individual buildings getting perfect adhesion to the build plate. Once the print is done the raft simply pulls apart from all the finished pieces.

author: udomuc

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1709143

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1709143

Using the following options:

Height = 15
Length = 55
Thick = 2
Width = 45

Bored by normal dices...? This design is for you!
With ultimate configurable DICE you can easily create your own dice, putting your custom engravings on every six faces! Moreover you can select the dice size, the roundness you want and the engraving depth, to create a unique dice that no one owns! All this without leaving Thingiverse, nothing more easy!!!
No more boring dices in your board games! Amaze your friends next time you'll play something that requires one or more dices!

What's included:

  • the OpenSCAD script that you can use in Thingiverse customizer to easily create your custom dice
  • 5 texture packs ready to use in your computer using OpenSCAD (instructions down in the page)
  • 5 STL files ready to print, one for every texture pack (size: 20 mm, roundness: 10, engraving depth: 1mm) if you're in a hurry

There is one of the texture packs that is a game by its own and was made to stimulate your fantasy... Please leave a comment if you'll use it! :)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Not less than 0,2mm / layer

Infill:

20%

Notes:

If you want a good balanced dice I recommend to slice with Slic3r and to use a 20-25% 3D honeycomb as infill. It's important to select shell thickness equal to bottom/top thickness so that every wall will have the same thickness. I'm using 1,2mm for both (you'll have to calculate that in slic3r, multiplying your hotend diameter by the number of shells you select and layer thickness by the number of top/bottom layers you select).
But even with a Cura infill the dice will spin in an acceptable randomness.

Post production for the perfect dice

If you want the absolutely perfect dice I recommend, after a successful good print:

  • sand the sides to remove excess layer trace and small imperfections
  • brush the dice with an epoxy resin
  • sand again the surface with finer and finer grain sandpaper until you're satisfied by the surface (don't worry if it's opaque)
  • paint the dice with a varnish paint
  • when dry paint the engravings with a different varnish paint color

This is for perfection. It will be enough for me to use only the last point :)

To create your own engravings

If you want to put something unique on every side of the dice you'll have just to create six square images of no less than 100x100 pixels (if the image is more than 100x100 it will be scaled to that size)
No colors needed, just greyscale is best. Create a black background and write/draw what you want on every face using white.
Take in account to leave some margin on each side to not overlap engravings with the end of the side.
If you use a roundness greater or equal to 10 think even that the face surface is a circle, so don't put anything in the image corner.
If roundness > 10 the texture faces will be automatically scaled to fit the reduced face.

This is the standard 5 texture as an example of a correct image To use texture packs (on your OpenSCAD)

If you want to generate custom size / roundness / engraving depth using OpenSCAD in your computer with a supplied texture pack you have two ways.
1) The easy way
Put the scad file in a folder and uncompress the texture pack in the same folder. Open the scad file and voilà!

2) If you want to thinker with multiple texture packs (like me!)
Put the scad file in a folder, create a subfolder for every texture pack you'll want to use and uncompress there the supplied texture packs zip, one for every subfolder.
Then open the scad file. At the beginning your dice will be without any engravings.
Locate, in the /* [Hidden] */ section the TextureFolder parameter and set it to the subfolder name of the texture pack you want to use, terminated with double backslash like this:
TextureFolder = "Textures-standard\\"
Press F5 and you'll generate engraving using that texture-pack!
Easy to change in a fast way without messing with filenames ;)

comments.author: ForAiur

comments.text:
I'm sorry that Thingiverse is taking so long to fix Customizer... I've tested myself and the error is the same you said. I've sent another support request to Thingiverse staff and I've seen the customizer comments page filled up with users telling the exact same error. Hope they fix it soon.
In the meanwhile if you want to use OpenScad there's nothing to learn, just follow these easy steps:
1) Download and install OpenScad from http://www.openscad.org/
2) Download the Ultimate_configurable_dice.scad file from files section and save it to a folder (let's say c:\Temp)
3) Put 6 png files named "1.png", "2.png", ... , "6.png" in the same folder where you put the Ultimate_configurable_dice.scad file (c:\Temp).
4) Double click on the Ultimate_configurable_dice.scad file. It opens up in OpenScad. Nothing to see, it's normal.
5) Press [F5] to preview the object so that you can see if it's ok. Hold down the left mouse button to rotate it and the mouse wheel to zoom in/out.
6) If you want to change some parameters (the same you find in Customizer), change the lines at the top of the code you find in the left pane (example: Roundness = 10, if you want a more square dice lower that value, if you want a more spheric dice use a higher value).
7) If images are raised instead of engraved you have to edit images and save them as negative.
8) If the preview seems ok (remember to press [F5] each time you want to see an updated preview) you can render the final object to print. To do so press [F6], wait (a lot of time...) then press the "STL" icon on the toolbar (the rightmost button) and save your printable STL file :)

comments.author: energywave

comments.text:
Oh, I understood where is the problem! OpenScad is very slow when there are much polygons. I strongly suspect you used texture that are more than the advised size (in the instructions of the model) of 100x100 pixels... In that case polygons become exponentially more. In fact in my description it was unclear (I'll change it) because I wrote that if the images are more than 100x100 they will be scaled to that size. But that's true ONLY if you use Thingiverse customizer, NOT if you use OpenScad, where the image you use will be used without modifications.
That said is up to you do decide how much details you want. Bigger images = longer rendering times but better details when printed, smaller images = shorter rendering times but less details on printed object. I've set the limit of 100x100 to be rendered in a reasonable time.
I'm happy, however, that you're finding my model useful and can't wait to see your dices!!! :)

Instructions

requires few screws to attach holder_attach_assembly to back plate of the tablet holder. The trickiest part for car newbies is how to attach holder_attach_assembly to the car itself:
1) locate the cigarette lighter plug underneath the dashboard
2) mount holder_attach_assembly so that circular opening is aligned to plu
3) while holding assembly, mark positions for three holes using sharp object (Phillips screwdriver would do)

5) attach with screws
6) put USB charger in place of the cigarette plug, and attach USB cable between tablet and the USB charger.
7) feel free to send me questions, and I can provide more detailed instructions!

title: Iron Grenadiers Hobgoblin superheavy tank (GI Joe)

description.text:
This tank was not in the 1980's GI Joe toy line, but I needed some more vehicles for Destro's Iron Grenadiers army to drive around in. It's a mash-up of (and heavily inspired by) other people's artwork that I found online. This is supposed to be a big vehicle, bigger than the MOBAT or anything else on the battlefield. Maybe 100 tons and armed with twin laser guns, missiles, rockets, and Gatling guns in the turret. It can also transport infantry and has a ramp on the back for them to climb in and out.

Printing is straightforward. Everything is printed bottom side down and with supports. It was modeled to be in scale with the actual size GI Joe toys from the 80's. I suggest you print this at 25% or it may have too much or too little detail.
I did not glue the turret or gun in place. They are a tight enough fit that they stay in whatever position you place them.

Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present). Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace, freedom and make silly little toys like these. People like you are actually "the real American heroes".

This file is a free download. No copyright issues to worry about, so you can do whatever you like with it; buy, sell, print for personal use. If you have been re-directed to this file from a source other than my site on thingiverse.com they have done so without my permission.

Happy gaming!

I printed about 30 of the original Lazor Blades by plasma2002 about 4 years ago. I am down to my last 5 & decided to remake them a little bit different Specifically the hands that hold the razor blade would get hit by the beam be turned to charcoal and loosing their grip. The arms were a bit thin for multiple beam strikes in the same area before being cut by the unfocused beam. The main body, when the beam passed over on a slow pass for thick material would flare up underneath cooking the bottom of the project.

With that I remade them with a hollow center, bigger hands to have more of a positive/longer grip on the blade & widened the arms. I made the blade length a little wider to accommodate the cheaper Harbor Freight razor blades.

These are not as cool as the original [cool face!], but they suit my needs a bit more.
If I ever get creative in 4 more years, I'll make them look like an octopus [but with 6 arms].
These were made from drops from other projects [that's why the stain]. Wood is 5mm underlayment from Home Depot - Cheap plywood!

The blade holding dimensions work well for my 40W laser [speed 25, power 100] & its kerf, but your milage may vary with a higher wattage beam or thinner/thicker kerf.

And the reason - a honeycomb board has a lot of little thin pieces of metal touching the project material that, when the laser beam hits, will scatter the beam in other directions causing flare up points which could damage the bottom of the project material. The Lazor Blade stands minimize this. Do use enough stands to keep the cut pieces from dropping down where, if overlapping another piece above, could be hit by the unfocused beam causing surface damage to the project piece top face. Best I can explain it, as is.
This thing was made with Tinkercad.

author: thailoz

description.text:
BOBUS THE TINKERER

Bobus the Tinkerer is a, well, tinkerer. He is fascinated with machines, and has always searched for a type of crystal that could power his machines. At the time, the only portable method of powering them was steam, but that all changed when he used a rare crystal, that he named Bobite, in one of his machines and it worked. He was very excited about the discovery, but there was a problem. Bobite was so incredibly rare that he could only find a few crystals. He was desperate to find a solution. He began trying to come up with a formula to make the crystals grow at an increased rate, but had no luck.

One day he accidentally spilled a mixture of crude oil, slug slime, intraocular fluid, and pigs’ blood onto the crystals. The crystals started to grow at in extreme rate, but they became unstable and exploded. The explosion destroyed Bobus' workshop and left him unconscious. He woke up in the hospital the next day. He had a concussion and some crystal shards were lodged in his skin. The surgeons did their best to remove all the shards, but could not guarantee that they were completely removed, as some shards were very small. Bobus went home and rebuilt his shop. The accident destroyed everything. His machines, his plans, and all of his crystals were gone.

Weeks later, he woke up with sharp pains on the side of his head. He looked in the mirror and found crystal clusters pushing through his skin. He went back to the hospital, but they said there was nothing they could do. On his walk home, Bobus started to see Bobite crystals forming on the sides of buildings, on the ground, and in trees. As the months rolled by, he started notice major crystal formation in the town. Bobus needed to find something to stop the crystals from growing any further.

After years of trying, Bobus was unable to find a reversing formula. The town was forced to evacuate. Bobus is the only person left in the town. The Bobite spread and covered almost half of his face and head, forcing Bobus to remove his right eye and replace it with a prosthetic. If Bobus cannot find a formula to reverse the rapid growth, the Bobite could encroach on the entirety of the Earth.

To Be Continued…

Thanks to the people who created the things I remixed. There is a colored and uncolored download. Bobus stands at 105 mm. tall at 100%.

title: Easy Print Kids Building Toys
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There's a bin of toys in my son's classroom that every kid likes to play with the most. His teacher says that these are both the most favourite and educational toys in her classroom. I have no idea what they are called or where to buy them, so I borrowed a few and reverse engineered them. They're super easy to print, to the point where the kids get confused as to which are original and which are printed. This is an easy way to get a lot of play time out of 3d prints, if you print a bucket full. Multiple colours for best effect!

I have some ideas of how to make these better. In time, I will remix better ones, adding more geometric figures than the set originally had.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Geetech Prusa i3b

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

No

Notes:

Just print. I used PLA, and it works wonderfully. Glue stick on the bed (not heated) made for a very good bond, there was zero curling. I used a 0.25mm layer height, and 0.5mm first layer. These were some of the easiest things I've ever printed.

I used Slic3r, and some prints came out a bit stiff to connect, so I adjusted the height of the model. If you have any issues with them being too loose or too tight, the only thing you need to do is scale the objects up or down in the Z-axis ONLY, and this will give you perfect fits.
The only thing I needed to do was use a knife to remove the odd whisker or two, and wash them in water to remove any glue residue.
I borrowed one of each design from the classroom, and using digital calipers, I drew them in the computer.
Free play time, creativity.  Identifying shapes and colours.

Free play time, creativity.  Identifying shapes and colours.  Build awesome things, and create stories around the things.  Keep in mind that they need to be taken apart before being put away, or they'll never fit back in the bucket.  A great activity to reinforce kids to clean up after play time.
Print and play.  You'll need a 3d printer, and some filament.  PLA works great, others probably do too.  You'll probably need a bin or bucket for storage.

print_settings.Notes:: Geared chuck jaws can clamp tightly (that's their job), so I'd recommend a full infill.

description.text:
This is a 3D printable auxiliary jaw set for clamping and drilling pen blanks or other small square stock in a chuck.

The square notch constrains the rotational direction, so if you were to try turning a piece using this in the chuck a tailstock would be necessary to constrain the piece axially, as the grip of the chuck/3D print combo on the wood would need to be tested for each piece.

The design is based off of the plans (using 1/2" plywood) from David Reed Smith's turning project website. If you want to make a version using wood, I'd highly recommend the guide below. His site is a great place to look for tips, tricks, and great ideas!
http://www.davidreedsmith.com/Articles/WoodAuxJaws/WoodAuxJaws.htm

The holes are for adding small magnets to help pull the faces back against the chuck until the chuck is tightened.

Please use appropriate PPE when using power tools, especially lathes! Face shield, safety glasses, and dust mask are a must!

author: jwerry

description.text:
Forget those boring 2D snowflake ornaments. This season decorate your holiday tree with one of these 3D modular geometric snowflake orbs.  
Inspired by ITSPHUN shapes (itsphun.com), and Mother Nature (organic snowflake design).  
Happy Holidays and Happy Making!

You will need 20 snowflakes. Either print snowflake_single.stl 19 times and snowflake_top.stl once, or print snowflake_all.stl which has all 20 pieces of the design and fits on the bed of a MakerBot Replicator 2.   
I used PLA, 2 shells, 75% infill, standard (0.20mm) resolution, no raft. Print time was ~ 2 hours for the entire design.  Use clear PLA for a realistic looking snowflake.  
For assembly, connect the notches in the snowflake together, using the picture as a guide. Make sure the notches slide all the way together. (Hint: start with 5 snowflakes connected in a ring, as shown in the picture with the green snowflakes. Think of it as a soccer ball with only the white hexagonal faces).  
If the fit is too tight for the material you are using, scale the model up 105%.  
For a smaller ornament, you can construct an octahedron, using only 8 snowflakes instead of 20.

title: Monoprice MP select mini extruder guide for Flexible Filament

description.text:
This is a sleeve/guide to prevent buckling of flexible filaments, and fits into the small gap between the extruder assembly and the start of the bowden tube & between the pinch roller & filament. As of this writing I have printed about 10 items with SainSmart Flexible Filament & have experience no buckling.

NOTE:
Is is necessary to remove the manually added support ring in the circular recess at the bottom after printing, & clean any debris from the hole & guide slot to suite the 1.75mm filament.

I saw some bookends of a giraffe a while back & decided to make my own with a guitar. I added the musical notes as an after thought to support the neck of the guitar.
First time figuring two axis of slots to line up.

This was made from 1/4" acrylic & glued with acrylic glue WeldOn #4. I used a 40W laser with speed 35, power 100 & 4 passes. Black items are to engrave, I cut he blue first & magenta lines 2nd. Just did, no real reason beyond visually separating the bookends from the guitar & musical notes.

Two suggestions/mistakes I made on this : 1) Don't work zoomed up all the time - I did and things looked sturdy enough. When lased out, the musical score lines were very thin to where one broke when being removed from the material. 2) Make a jig or use clay to support the guitar neck while the glue dries. I did not. I just leaned it against an overhanging book to prop against the neck of the guitar. The neck angled out & now it is not at the same angle as the body of the guitar on the other bookend - Not noticeable with many books in-between, but 3 or less....much more noticeable.

comments.text: That [1/4" clear acrylic] was what I had on hand. Colored acrylic would look quite a bit better. I toyed with he idea of adding a slow color cycling RGB LED to each side, but did not want to deal with batteries/wall wart & doing the single LED on each side - the color cycle would get out of sync [not talking about adding a micro controller, but a single RGB LED that self cycles]. This was a 'just finish the project' & get to the next backlogged one!

Parametric spur gears (and rack) library that uses OpenSCAD list comprehension to build the polygons resulting in much faster compile and render.

The library includes functions for determining the pitch radius for your gears to allow the gears to be placed within your design such that they mesh properly (see the gear test example).

description.text:
kee klamp
Model Number: 10-6
Dimensions: For 1" Schedule 40 Pipe Size

Threads can be cleaned up with a .375-16 tap and die.

This is a mount for an LCD keypad that I'm intending to use with the excellent SJFW firmware on my mendelmax. There is also a position for a small piece of vero board to mount connectors and resisters for the LEDs etc.
The two large holes are 20mm diameter and will take a standard illuminated automotive switch as found on ebay, one will be used for the printer on/off and the second will control the strips of LEDs I will fit along the inside of the frame for printing in the dark :-). The five small holes on the bottom right are for LEDs to show when the heated bed and hot end etc are active with space to the left for labels.
The keypad is sticky backed, and there is a small slot for the ribbon cable.
This is also one of the largest single objects I have printed as it only just fits on my prusa.
Switches have arrived, see the new picture.

1) Print it ;-)
2) Bolt in LCD with 4 off M3 x 20mm bolts plus nuts and washers
3) Cut a piece of vero board, 40mm x 100mm and drill 4 holes with a spacing of 20mm by 90mm
4) Drill the four PCB mounting points to fit 4 small self tapping screws, and mount the vero board
5) Drill the five LED positions to match your LED, mine will be blue 3mm I haven't got this far yet, as the parts haven't arrived... 6) Glue the LEDs in position with a hot glue gun
7) Push the two large switches into position, they should be self fixing
8) Connect everything back up.

description.text: Bracket to mount two 2.5" (laptop) hard drives in place of a single 3.5" (desktop) hard drive.

I didn't require support material (The overhangs are gradual). This is intended to be used with M3 hardware (which is what hard drives normaly use).   
The slots for the m3 nuts are intentionally a bit tight to prevent spinning once installed. If you have trouble getting them in, a trick I use is to hold the nut in place against the slot and heat it up with a soldering iron, once hot it will slide right through the PLA and get locked in place. Note that if you do this, the nut will stay hot for quite awhile because it is only in contact with PLA which is a relatively poor conductor of heat.

This is a mini fpv mount for the E010: http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-E010-Mini-2_4G-4CH-6-Axis-Headless-Mode-RC-Quadcopter-RTF-p-1066972.html?rmmds=myorder
And the Eachine mini fpv set: http://www.banggood.com/Eachine-TX01-Super-Mini-AIO-5_8G-40CH-25MW-VTX-600TVL-14-Cmos-FPV-Transmitter-p-1088374.html?rmmds=myorder

All of these mini fpv sets are slightly different, so i made one to suit the one i got.
This has a 15deg tilt.
The hoop is a little bit of a loose fit, so you don't have to trim it to get it in, use a little glue to keep it in there.
The fpv unit is a little loose as well, use a little glue to keep it in there.
The 4 spacers give it clearance off the circuit board.
You will need to find another 2 tiny screws so you can have all 4 points secured.

title: Square Pixel Seating Jig for Boscoyo Strips
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a jig for rapidly seating square type pixels in a boscoyo strip. See this video on use:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YMnP4Oy9I24

I recommend you print this at .3mm layers with 50% infill for strength. I printed mine out of ABS but PLA is probably a viable material as well.

After I got my routine down, it takes me about 12:30 to seat 60 pixels AND do a 4 wiretie splice to connect 2 strips together. Thats nearly 5 strips per hour. And thats just a leisurely pace. I wasn't racing, just getting it done. And thats with no hurting fingers!

author: katrule

description.text:
Decided to build a prop DL-44 blaster using a cheap airsoft Mauser C96 from eBay.
While there is a good kit for the ANH version (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:882673 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1245642) there are only a few parts for the ESB version(s).

Wanting a challenge I thought to try my hand and replicating the flash hider, m-19 scope, bracket and all the greeblies from scratch. This is a work in progress, waiting on the blaster and some more filament to come in the post before I can begin this project

All parts were modeled from drawings and images i found from around the web. For parts I knew only a few dimensions of I took them into ImageJ (https://imagej.nih.gov/ij/) and did my best to take measurements.

I'm sure by the time I am done with this some pieces and parts will have changed and I will have added more.

11/29: Added a new flash hider and motor-coil greeblie with larger lettering for better printing.

12/25: finished the Blaster. Worked on creating a plate cover for the non-scope side of the gun to make it more accurate to the originals, wasn't happy with my drawing in 123d design so ended up making this by hand from a few layer thick piece of ABS rectangle I had printed. The Motor-Coil greeblies were printed with shapeways as my flashforge wasn;t getting all the details. It only cost $5 so It was worth it. I oversized the piston half greeblies just a bit (105% or there bout) while not accurate to movie, looked better to me. I also printed a thicker bracket and used a washer behind the scope bracket to give a better asthetic (again in my opinion, not necessarily movie accurate). #d printed some 1/4 20 bolts which i cut down to fit in the scope bracket. Had to drill a few holes in the scope to get them to fit. I kept the airsoft intact with its firing capabilities. All screws and such are just epoxied in place (many of the screws are cut just below the screw head).

title: Magnetic Cable Organiser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Soooo many cables! Magnets to the rescue.

These little clips just push fit over your cable and take all the hassle out of cable management. Ideal for that phone/watch/tablet charger next to your bed or go bigger and use them in the workshop. When you're done with the cable you just hold it in the vicinity of the wall mount and it will snap into place - I love neodymium magnets!

Designed for the magnets listed below. Magnets just push fit in.

NOTE : these are designed for use with a semi flexible filament like the hobbyking branded flexible filament :
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/flexible-3d-printer-filament-white.html

I love this stuff. It's nowhere near as flexible as ninjaflex but it's much much easier to print. I've even had success with it on a fabricator mini which has a bowden extruder and no heated bed, so no excuses! Just need to slow down the extrusion - but these clips are small so the print time is fast anyway.

round magnets - 15mm x 4mm:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/OMO-Magnetics-Lots-50pcs-Super-Strong-Round-Magnets-15mm-x-4mm-Disc-Fridge-Rare-Earth-Neodymium/32577994760.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.HgiVX5

rectangular magnets - 10mm x 5mm x 3mm:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/100pcs-Strong-Block-Magnets-10mm-x-5mm-x-3mm-Rare-Earth-Neodymium-Magnets-N35/1518061569.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.HgiVX5

The "tightFit" models have a smaller circumference for the circular magnets and a slightly (0.5mm) deeper hole for them.

Printer:

wanhao duplicator v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 or less

Infill:

10 to 20

Notes:

Meant to be printed in flexible. In theory pla or abs would be fine but you'd want to wider the gap in the cable clips so that the cable can be pushed in.

comments.text: If you don't have flex filament you can also put the thing in hot water for a few seconds and quickly slide the cable in the gap before it hardens again. :-)

For D&D we use a system of 10, 10 copper = 1 silver, 10 silver =1 gold. I like to give my player coins to hold on to and I included a holder, I only let them change coins at the bank so they have to be in town to do so. it gives it a better feel to the game. I also found gems and different colors at the dollor store, but I was never able to find coins with holes in the middle. This way they could string the coins if needed. The holder has space in the bottom to hold 2 - 1" washers to help weigh the holder down. I spray paint the coins copper, silver, and gold. The coins are meant to be 1" in diameter. the holder just a bit larger all the way around.

Key holder to your door knob. Very handy if you are a bit bad with your memory. Might need resizing. Please comment if you see something wrong with the model. This is not done by professional but I tried to think many aspects of the need of this model. Text might need a bit precise printer but it should work even without it. I'll try to fix the model if needed.

Blender

I created it with Blender. I'm holding the original .blend which I use to derivate the STL so it might be a bit hard for you to make any tiny or pretty changes. I'm not making money with it and I try to provide new STL models if needed. For handy Blender expert this shouldn't be problem to make similar but still I decided to keep the source which is needed for creating similar model with different text.

I started form cube, flattened model, made few subdivisions, carved the top curve and key hole, inserted text with UV mapping and made a displacement with UV map. All in mentioned order. Should be enough precise instructions for handy modeler.

Now you can make your own or ask me to provide better model. I'm having a model before displacement map so it's easy to replace with new text. Sorry for the large amount of vertexes. I was a bit lazy with modeling so there is a lot of unnecessary vertexes. I'm not sure if that is though a problem. I hope not :)

description.text:
I had an old Pentax lens sitting around collecting dust, so I decided to try and mount it to my Nikon camera. I designed this lens mount adapter to use Pentax PK mount lenses on a Nikon camera body that uses the F-Mount. The focal length is very short, almost a macro.
Be sure to either use a dark filament or paint it black as there will be light leaks otherwise. I only printed it in white to show detail better. The last three photos are taken with the lens mounted on the adapter.

Hi! In Simplify3d, for example, double click on process, then go to tab "Scripts" - "Starting script". The code that you see in this window is telling a printer what to do right before printing. Usually there will be G28 - himing all axes. In order to clean hotend you have to add something like:
G1 X90 Y5 // (go to 90 mm mark on X axis, 5 mm on Y)
G1 X80 Y5
To figure out exact parameters play with manual controls.

print_settings.Notes:: For the Disc and the Bolt Tool use 100% infill!

description.text:
I designed these X-carriages to fit my needs. They are, for the most part, the same as the original carriages that came with the kit.
The major reason in creating these was to ensure the correct distance between the two ilders in relation to the guided rods.

Assembly instructions:

  • Make sure both X-guide rods are 436mm in length.
  • For easier insertion I recommend burring the end of the 436mm guide rods first. This makes it easier to insert them into the idlers.
  • Due to tolerances in the print I also recommend using an 8mm drill to smooth the holes on the carriage. Only one careful pass is necessary. The rods must still fit snugly!
  • Insert the 2 rods in the left carriage until they reach the end.
  • Mount the completely assembled extruder to the guided X-rods.
  • Carefully mount the right carriage to the guide rods until it reaches the end.
  • Now you can mount the whole extruder assembly with carriages and X-guide rods to the Z-guide rods.

I've also included an X-carriage tensioner. I thought this solution was a great idea to tension the belt : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1683070
You will need 2 x M3x25mm screws and 2 x M3 nuts to mount the tensioner to the right carriage.

The disc is for straightening the threaded shaft should it be off center and doesn't freely go through the top frame hole. To make corrections you will need to sand the disc to the appropriate angle for correct fit.

I also recommend that the linear bearing be positioned in the center of the carriage. For this I created a bolt tool that can be used to push the bearing all the way in until the bolt tool is even with the carriage surface.

These carriages are not a must have. Print them out if want to do some small improvements.

Please let me know if you have a problem with the design so I can improve it if necessary.

Also please post a picture with comments if you have made one.

Thanks.

Leo

Update 21.1.2017:

I've added a second version of the left motor carriage. It now has a channel for the X-stop cable.

Update 25.1.2017:

Version 1.1 of both carriages. The X-stop switch has been re-positioned making it easier to lay the cable behind the carriage. Some small modifications were also made.

Update 18.4.2017:

Uploaded "X_Idler_Right_Tensioner-9.4_Leo_N" to accommodate GT2-16/20 pulley.

Update 24.5.2017:

Uploaded "X_Idler_Right_Tensioner-9.0_Leo_N" to accommodate GT2-16/20 pulley for well calibrated printers.

Update 7.6.2017:

Uploaded "X_Idler_Right_Tensioner-11.4_Leo_N" to accommodate GT2-16/20 pulley (11mm wide) for 6mm belts.

comments.text:
Before you download and print this, check the distance between the x axis smooth rods that you have, and compare it to the values for this. I found that there was a 1.75mm difference between this mount and the anet supplied mounts. This means that the x axis bearings will bind due to the holes in the extruder mount not being the correct distance. It may be that Anet drill and print the parts bespoke to each printer... which also means the tolerances can be large between different printers.
You may have to make 4 of the x axis bearing holes on the extruder mount more oval or slotted to accommodate the different distance.

comments.text:
If your rods are exactly as I described then you most likely have debris in the holes so that the rods are not going all the way to the end of the idlers. Did you bevel / burry the edges of the rods before inserting them into the idlers like I described?
I any case you can use a clean 8mm drill to clean up the holes. Remember you want a tight fit so the rods don't have any movement.
That the holes don't go through is by design. That is one of the main points for designing these. That way people can't press the idlers close together otherwise too may forces act on the guide rods.

comments.text: Thanks for posting.   Why did you print at .28 resolution instead of a number that is more directly related to your top/bottom layer thickness?
comments.author: Mediocredesigns

comments.text:
The Anet printer uses Nema 17 stepper motors (1.8°) and the thread pitch of the threaded rod is 8mm -> 1.8° / 360° * 8mm = 0.04mm.
So you would then use layer heights in 0.04- 0.08 - 0.12 - 0.16 - 0.20 - 0.24 - 0.28 .... steps.
For fine print quality I use 0.12, normal quality 0.20 and for draft 0.28.
comments.author: Mediocredesigns

comments.text: Did not really plan on using them since I printed them to use as spares in case my stock pieces would break when disassembling the rods (which I have heard of) when chaning the X-carrige. They did not break.... but when swapping to the new carrige equiped with  Igus bearings the stock pieces made the rods pinch the whole carrige, making it stuck. Pretty upset I thought the X-carrige was faulty... but then I tried the spare parts that I had printed.... and WOW!!! These are so much better. The X-carrige moves much easier, and I also tried the old carrige, and that also moved much easier. I guess my stock pieces were crap from the start, but the original bearing hid the troubles that became so very obvious with new bearings, Anyway, great design and flawless funtionality!

comments.text: Could you make a drawing and send it to me at removed. I'm still a bit confused as to what you have in mind.
comments.author: KmanOz

comments.text: Let me explain it a little more. I can't draw for shit. From the right hand side of the idler, create a small channel that fits the wire from the X Stop on the underneath of the idler that will follow the contour of the idler around the smooth rod. You can then tuck the wire in the channel. You may need to make the idler a little thicker to do so. The channel goes on the underneath from right to left hand side of the idler to allow the wire to come out near the stepper motor plug where it will be cable tied to the stepper motor cable and head to the controller. From the front you will see the wire go into the idler and on the left hand side exit the idler. It will neaten the whole thing up and there will be no possibility of a the cable being caught somewhere by mistake. Does that make sense?

Not new and adjustment not easy as you have to play with two screws. How do you measure the belt tension when adjusting ?
Better a simple U shape holding the pulley with one screw plus butterfly nut to hold and adjust.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I did not say it was new. I said I made the items for my needs.
Having 2 screws is easy to adjust. Why 2 screws? Because both screws press against the guide rods so no force is applied to the right idler which is important. That is why a U shape tension holder is not the best thing to do.
How do I adjust the belt tension? Look at the belt on the stepper motor shaft end. Now move the extruder back and forth. If the belt on the stepper motor side moves up or down then you need to tighten it. If it stays level then it is tight enough.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: No,  a U shape is better, simpler. The proper way to adjust the belt tension is to use a scale to measure the tension. Easy when you have only one screw, just attach the scale to the said screw and pull it to measure ! I adjust it to 26 N.

remixed_from.title: Smartphone Photo Studio for #3DBenchy and tiny stuff

title: Smartphone Photo Studio for #3DBenchy and tiny stuff Remixed Large Parts

description.text:
This is a work in progress. Please take a look at the original for some detailed info. What I did here was modify some of the larger pieces to fit on a smaller build plate.

The pieces modified have the 3DBenchy title removed from the file name, and are all hooked together with dovetail pieces. The phone holder is not cut down as it prints on a diagonal fairly well and I was worried about how they'd fit together.

issues and notes:

  • The pieces that have been split are snug and may require some light hammer taps to slide together.
  • If you can avoid a brim, that would be best.
  • There is a known height issue with the male/female main pieces, it's negligable to me, but if requested I'll try and fix it up.
    -The modular rail is completely optional! I did it so I could more distance from a model and thus a larger photo area.
  • The Male piece on the rear has two versions; one is the basic version from the original 3d Benchy, the other is an "Extended Height" piece. For my phone it was worthwhile to go higher and had a larger bigger camera hump. I personally recommend this one for more photo options, but the phone holder arm may not be enough. If I can revise the arm, I'll update later on.

Other than those notes, everything else is a bout the same as the original benchy smartphone studio!

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

15

Notes:

Support's only really needed for the phone holding bar and the turntable holder. I'd suggest no brim for the parts that have been cut with a dovetail, otherwise you'll have more than expected cleanup.
Double check the dovetails and shave down the edges as needed for fit. Also, if possible, double check heights and connection pieces, some may need shaving.
Umm, all work is credit to the original photo studio by 3D Benchy. I merely cut down a few pieces for my printer and modified the phone holder so I could take taller model pictures.

author: poken1151

description.text:
Almost fully printable and fully functional RC Rally Chassis ready for your electronics and some additional parts... which are simply not printable. German Documentation:
Part 1: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uf2V-1DWsiM
Part 2: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6pzKIgqWE4k
Part 3: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CFaxIND3oXo Actual driving: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rtneCSx_AAA

This is a fully functional RC Rally Chassis. I got sick of the money I have to pay for replacement parts for my RC Cars so I decided to construct my own. So now I can print my own parts for it and I can make them as strong as I like them to be. Additional parts you need: Several screws, mostly 3mm
2 x LRP S10 Blast TX / TC differentials including housing
4 x Kyoscho TF-02 Spider suspension or compatible. But these have a lot of travel which you want on a rally car
4 x Bling39 CVD cardan drive shafts
8 x ball bearings 11x4x5mm
1 x LRP S10 Blast TX pinion gear with slipper clutch
1 x middle drive shaft from the LRP S10 Blast TX - but it needs to be modified to fit the chassis
1 x push rod for the servo to be connected to the steering I believe these are the main parts. But these are the parts that usually don't break! So it's ok to buy them ;) The chassis plate is devided into three parts to keep it printable. It is strengthend by 4mm threaded rods and two additional aluminium bars that are connected to the side of the chassis. The buttom of the chassis itself is strengthend with 0.5mm aluminium which can be easiely made cut by hand and then glued to the chassis plate. I also glued the motor mount to the chassis to make it sand prove. The motor cap is missing. I got slightly lazy but you can cut some thick paper and bend it to use it as the cap. I printed the whole thing massive. Meaning: set fill to 1! I know, that is extremly expensive - but still way cheaper than buying replacement parts all the time... One last thing: The upper suspension arms are too thick on the outside. That is on purpose! I wanted my printer to print them correctly and then cut them back as needed. I also used some metal tubes to strengthen all moving parts. So I drilled 3.9mm holes and put the rod in and then cut them. This way the plastic does not wear off so quickly.
The bumper should be replaced by some thick foam because the ABS version will break on first contact! Comments are extremly welcome :)

This is a mod of the X car for the Tevo Tarantula to allow the use of the Flexion Extruder by Diabase.

It is design to use the direct extruder of Diabase with a BL Touch sensor for autobed levelling.

This mod use the belt lock of the excellent modular X car basic by Thingirob (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1438795).
Also, due to the extra-weight on the X axis, I strongly recommend to reinforce it. In my case, instead of adding a second Z rod, I use the lead screw bearing holder by Colindo
(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1784630).
I keep the original X axis motor of the tarantula in order to have enought torque for the extruder.

This mod needs the following printable parts:

  • Direct Flexion Extruder X car (file n°1 V1 or V2, see below for differences)
  • BL touch sensor spacer (file n°2)
  • Dedicated fan duct (file n°3)
  • Belts Locks (2) (you can find it here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1438795)

And the following non-printable parts :

  • 2 M3x40 screws to hold the extruder motor from the back
  • 2 M3x35 screws to hold the whole extruder assembly on the motor
  • The Flexion Extruder by Diabase and its accessories
  • The BL touch sensor

X & Y Probe Offsets for BL Touch :
X Probe offset from nozzle: - 4 mm
Y Probe offset from nozzle: 64 mm

I strongly recommend to do a PID autotune after the installation.

Specials thanks to Austin Reid from Diabase for his advice.

########## Note ##########
I just added a V2 edit of the X-car, the new version make it easier to place the screws and has a reinforcement of the belt locking system.
#########################

Relevant links:

  • Diabase Flexion Extruder - https://flexionextruder.com/
  • BL Touch sensor -
    https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bltouch-auto-leveling-sensor-for-3d-printers

description.text:
I have designed this Heart-In-Heart as a gift for my girlfriend's birthday. The most romantic move I've done in last few years :) so she appreciated it, even it does not say "Swarovski". It does look fantastic after all.

The inner hear should have been easy removable but in my print they did fit tight, so we will not be able to remove them. I've modified the design and increased the gap with 0.1mm gap on both parts, so that they will fit easier.

Later will think about designing a holder for the heart. Or maybe somebody will do it on their own.

Printer:

Custom built CoreXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Be prepared, this print will eat a lot of plastic - my print weights 136 grams at 20% infill (Simplify3D estimates ~20m of yellow plastic and ~2.7m of red plastic).

0.2mm layer is smooth enough, much more if you use something to smooth the surface.

print_settings.Notes:: I preferred to use the Outline direction: Outside-In.

title: Mason Jar Funnel for Pressure Canning

description.text:
This is a funnel for filling mason jars. It's for a pint & half pint jars with mouths around 2 1/4" wide.
It is oblong shaped on top to make pouring into the funnel easier while maintaining a smaller storage footprint.

I designed the item as a solid object with the small side down to make it easier to print on less than perfect beds.
To print use 0 infill and top/bottom layers. Adjust the number and thickness of perimeters to make the part as thick as you want.

author: creuzerm

title: Xaircraft SuperX GPS mount for Xcope

description.text:
Massive GPS mount for Xaircraft SuperX GPS Puk to use on a Xcope Frame.

To connect the upper and the lower mounting parts, use a 8 mm Carbon Tube. For quick disassembly there is a option to connect the frame mount and the lower GPS mount with a M3 screw.

The lower mount is constructed to carry the SuperX Status LED inside. It has an angle of 45° to have a good view to the LED from ground.

Take a Deo Roller ball (37 mm) and cut it half. Set it over the Status LED. Now you have a big and bright Lens for your Status LED

Nozzle_Fillet_Radius = 3

Instead of putting your presents beneath the tree, why not put them on the tree? This is an ornament that also functions as a reusable present box. It's lockable with a nice ornate key. In addition to the key, the ribbons also hold the lid on and add an extra puzzle nature to the box. It can be a fun challenge for young kids to try to figure out how to open it. I'm using this with my kids and they are very intrigued about what might be in the box. They're already asking for the key! I'm planning to put the keys in their stockings. Check out the video for how it works and how to assemble: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8MNviO8Qv2c

Watch the video for assembly instructions.  
If you are printing with ABS and are experiencing warping/lifting for the box or the lid, try the "Anti-warp" versions. Use a raft, and the extra disks should keep the corners down.  
For the key, it's best to use a raft and supports as the model only touches the build-plate in one place.  
If the ribbons are printing with too tight a fit (does this happen more often with PLA?) you can upsize the inner ribbon (Ribbon_Part_1) to 101% an the outer ribbon (Ribbon_Part_2) to 101.5%. Thanks dssguy1 for this tip!

comments.text: well i can see???
comments.author: MacGyver

comments.text: It's only useful when using a raft. A raft will help prevent against  ABS corner curling, but for larger flat-bottomed models, I've found the corners are often not protected as much as needed. Since the raft is larger than the footprint of the model, the raft of the box merges with the raft of the disks thus extending the grip to the build platform at the corners. Seems to work well in my tests....
comments.author: MacGyver

comments.text: It's useful when using a raft. The raft forms a base that is larger than the footprint of the model, and when this happens the raft of the box and the raft of the disks merge forming an extended raft at the corners. I've found that the default rafts don't protect corners as well as they should when printing large flat-bottomed objects, so this trick extends them and seems to work pretty well.
comments.author: MacGyver

comments.text: I've found that connecting the disks with the actual model, like you can do in Makerware, makes a raft unnecessary.  I understand what you are saying about extending the raft, however, I prefer no raft if I can help it at all.
